frameDefinitions: A linguistic Form has a particular Meaning, possibly restricted to a particular Context.
One linguistic unit, Sign_1, has a relation to another linguistic unit, Sign_2.
A Speaker realizes a Sign, usually a linguistic one, in some Formal_realization.
An Entity began its existence in the context of a Origin, which can be a place,  culture, time period, text, etc.
A person (Speaker) expresses a Message or mental content, broadly understood, in a particular Manner.
One phenomenon, the Predictive_phenomenon is an indication of the future or current (but still uncertain) existence of another phenomenon, the Future_phenomenon.
frameExamples: 'Unicorn' <t>denotes</t> a mythological horse with a horn on its head.
A person doesn't always <t>pronounce</t> a word the way they say  it in context
The Christian <t>origin</t> of this quote is from Isaiah 22.
listRoleDefinitions: <fen>Form</fen> is the formal pole of a linguistic sign.
<fen>Meaning</fen> is the sense of a linguistic <fen>Form</fen>.
<fen>Referent</fen> identifies an object in the real (or a hypothetical) world that a linguistic expression is used to talk about.
FN: a linguistic unit that carries semantic, phonological or syntactic information.
FN: a linguistic unit
FN: Linguistic units
The language user who produces a <fen>Sign</fen> in some modality.
An abstract form-meaning pairing.
An evaluation of whether the <fen>Formal_realization</fen> that the <fen>Speaker</fen> produced matches the standard or standard range.
The written string, gesture, or vocalized sound sequence that the <fen>Speaker</fen> produces.
A constituent part of the <fen>Formal_realization</fen>.
The way that the <fen>Speaker</fen> produces the <fen>Formal_realization</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Speaker</fen> produces the <fen>Formal_realization</fen>.
The item whose <fen>Origin</fen> is under discussion.
The place or culture where the <fen>Entity</fen> was produced.
<fen>Speaker</fen>, the person who encodes the <fen>Message</fen>, occurs as the External Argument of all the verbs:
The <fen>Message</fen> is almost invariably expressed in an NP Object. (The only exceptions occur with the verb <t>express</t>, which is occasionally used with that-clause complements.)

For most of the words in this frame, some expression of <fen>Manner</fen> or <fen>Medium</fen> is obligatory. As in other frames, <fen>Manner</fen> expressions characterize the action (in this case, the speech act performed by the <fen>Speaker</fen>). However, a wide range of <fen>Manner</fen> expressions occurs in this frame, including the following types:
<fen>Medium</fen> expresses the <fen>Medium</fen> of communication, such as the language used or the specific type of text in which the <fen>Message</fen> occurs:
<fen>Predictive_phenomenon</fen> provides evidence for the existence or the nature of the <fen>Outcome</fen> of <fen>Future_phenomenon</fen>.
<fen>Future_phenomenon</fen> is that phenomenon that is predicted to occur or have a particular quality.
The role <fen>Outcome</fen> identifies those expressions that indicate how the <fen>Future_phenomenon</fen> is expected to turn out based on the evidence of the <fen>Predictive_phenomenon</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the omen is occuring.
The location where something good or bad might occur.
listRoleExamples: In one sense, <fex>dog</fex> is a hyponym of itself.
In one sense, dog is a hyponym of <fex>itself</fex>.
<fex>He</fex> insists on mispronouncing my name every time, the bastard!
Finally, I would pay more attention to your 'oppinion' if you spelled it <fex>correctly</fex>.
The old uncensored editions of the Talmud referred to Jesus as Yeshua censored versions spelled it <fex>as Yeshu</fex>
You spelled it <fex>the way it sounds</fex>.
The Prime Minister expressed <fex>her sympathy for the victims</fex>.
True Manner: You should phrase it <fex>carefully</fex>.
<fex>To achieve so much this year</fex> augurs well for the future.
This move presages <fex>a freeze on the granting of new concessions</fex>.
It all bodes <fex>well</fex> for the future.
The storm bodes ill for you <fex>here</fex> .

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the first 52 months of the PS2
